commentBody: This was not a novel theme, and it was much too easy for a Thursday puzzle. A disappointing 2/10 for me.
It always makes me feel good when I struggle with the clues and find the "tricky clues" section starting with how none of the clues were tough..

....and not a rebus in sight.



(I hope everyone can see the teeny circles.)

I think the hardest part was realizing how this wasn't a terribly tricky Thursday puzzle. My brain kept looking for zebras. 

Nice to just enjoy and not struggle.

What do you think? Do the extra visual cues in this puzzle enhance or detract from your solving experience? Please let me know in the comments.


Daniel,
I would have liked to have tried it as you submitted it, with no little circles. To me, that would have been a Thursday.
I enjoyed this one; the coin didn't drop until near the end.
I got all the gimmick answers by solving the crossing clues. Then, I read the blog, and it didn't click for quite awhile. Even so, I was happy to get a solve in a little less than my average time.
So how do I get to be a crossword tester 🤔

I enjoyed it a lot.  It might not have been terribly difficult, but that’s why we have the weekend puzzles.  What I like to get (and got) on a Thursday is a fun twist.  I agree it didn’t need any more cues to get the idea.

To the editors: This triumvirate of answers was too simple in my estimation to make it a Thursday puzzle. 

To the constructor: Thank you. Always thank you. I enjoyed it. I always enjoy the puzzle whether I’m successful or not. Thank you constructors- keep them coming!

This puzzle hit the old SWEET SIXTEEN of solving fun.
It delivered its aha moment right to my AREA FIFTYONE.
There was just that moment when I had to CATCH TWENTYTWO before returning to earth with the trick.

(That’s after I corrected my initial impression those were little smiley faces.) 😀

Just 16 seconds slower than my Thursday PR. 

I liked it.
I liked the theme, but that was way too easy. Time to dive into the archive for something with more meat.
I'm terrible and slow and this took me 14 minutes,  about my fastest time ever for any puzzles. says my average Thursday is 48 minutes. Way too easy!

My first gold star on a Thursday puzzle!  Woohoo!

The theme hit me about half way in once I figured out SPOT replaced SIXTEEN.  The other two easily filled in and made the crosses move quickly.  

A fun puzzle!

I really enjoyed this puzzle. I think a Thursday best for me, and this one was a lot of fun throughout. The cluing and fill were both clever and funny.

Notably, for the first time ever, I managed to fill in the second and third themed answers without reading the clues or using a single cross. Once I got “Sweet 16” and noticed the highlight on 16A, I checked the other two highlighted numbers. ___ 22 could only be one thing, and ___ 51 could only be one thing. So, I confidently filled in the other two spanners. It felt really satisfying to figure out such long answers that way.

A fun, funky, and fast Thursday. Thanks, Daniel Bodily!
Nice.  I had to read the column to understand 1A (Strike one= pose) and I thought novice gamers were usually NOOBS rather than NEWBS.  Fun and quickish for a Thursday.

No complaints here. TBH I often skip Thursdays b/c of  the oblique clues  and the various other challenges thrown in!  But this one was fun!  I caught on to the "sweet sixteen" right away so it was pretty much smooth sailing from there! My time ended up being  *half* my average for Thursdays!❤️

Such fun.  I let out a very long ohhhhhhhhh when I realized what was going on, when seeing 51D could be CODES. The passage from confusion to comprehension never stops being a delight.  

And congrats to Daniel Bodily on getting a 15x14 grid accepted.  We are in AREA FIFTY ONE indeed!

Not sure how I feel about this one.  I'm inclined to say that it's too easy and that the theme wasn't good enough for a coveted Thursday spot.  Even the constructor calls it a trifling "fun little puzzle".

On the other hand the theme was clever and well executed.  It probably didn't need the gold numbers - I kept waiting for something a lot more exciting than what we got.  I guess in the end it was an "okay" puzzle but I always hope for a bit more wondrousness on a Thursday.

Still, "mind repeating that" and "word after one fell" were REALLY clever, and appreciated.

Last couple of weeks now have been marred by easier entries, or so it seems.

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)

For Daniel Bodily’s question:

“What do you think? Do the extra visual cues in this puzzle enhance or detract from your solving experience? Please let me know in the comments.”

I enjoyed the yellow circles. It was very satisfying when the mystery cracked.

If "Hang Ten" is serious air time, then surely "Catch Twenty Two" is even more serious air time. And if a typical bat is 32 inches, then the middle 16 inches is likely its (quite large) sweet spot, its "sweet sixteen." Contorted thinking got me that far, but couldn't process the two-digit area code "Fifty One" till I remembered with joy: +51 is how I call my friend in Lima. Mulishly, I tried as hard as possible to disregard the little yellow numbers, and I sorta wish that, even if they had to be there, that they weren't conveniently located right next to their themed answers. We are all rugged individualists in these parts, no matter who we are in the real world.

That said, the NW was the devil for me, and I truly enjoyed Balayage. Next time I go to the salon I'm getting a mani-pedi-bali. (Only problem with balding is that it diminishes the usefulness of balayage treatments, but that's the only problem).
Really enjoyed this puzzle after coming home from my evening shift! That aha moment was so worth it!
Felt like a Tuesday in a Thursday slot to me. Would have been more compelling without explicitly calling out the substitutions

Who knew that tubas "BOOM"ed ?  

Timpani and other drums boom, perhaps an electric bass guitar can boom, but a tuba? 

Maybe an OOMPA, or OOMPAHPAH, or a BLAT, or maybe even a SPLAT, but not a BOOM!

Not buying it.

Happy SWEET(forty) to me! A fun puzzle to kick off my quickly crossing over the proverbial hill. 

I personally am never one to complain about a puzzle being too easy, but prefer to pat myself on the back for a good solve, and congratulate the constructor on an enjoyable creation.

Olá!

Most of my entries on the first pass were correct, which they usually are not on Thursdays. I got hung up in the expected places — “Why is it AREAFIFTYONE instead of area CODES? 🤔” and NEWB instead of noob. Then I worked through it pretty quickly for a fast finish. 

Like others, I was waiting for the other rebus-adorned shoe to drop. When the theme was straight forward, it was a bit of a relief. 

I think we’re in for a head-scratching weekend with this relatively easy Thursday puzzle. Enjoyed it MUCHO, Mr. Bodily. You were a SÃO for not making it too difficult for us.

IGA's name is Świątek, not Swiatek. It seems disrespectful to misspell a person's name. I suppose having accurate and respectful clues about Slavs is still not the NYT's thing.

I've never heard of a family having matching PJS - the idea sounds quite creepy TBH. That was one of the most arcane clues I have ever seen in these puzzles.

The theme was interesting and gettable - I caught onto it quickly and it helped me complete the puzzle, which always feels better than only understanding some convoluted gimmick after reading the column.
When I looked at this on my computer, and then printed it, there was no highlighting of clue numbers, as described in the column.

After the first pass on the across entries, I only had 3 answers filled in and was worried I would be in for a rough time. The first pass at the downs helped a bit. However, this was one of those puzzles where once you got a toehold, opened right up. I'm shocked that I finished in 1/2 my average time. But most importantly, when I finished, I was smiling because so many of the clues were fresh and clever. Overall, a very fun puzzle with some sparkling wit. .

This was fun and the little yellow circled numbers clued me in to where to look to understand what I'd just done - for all I knew, SWEET SIXTEEN really was the sweet spot on a bat, and HANG TWENTY-TWO seemed a reasonable slangy extension from surfing's hang ten, given skateboarders' free-spirited ways. Then when I got down to AREA FIFTY-ONE I could fill it in before I got the crosses.

What tripped me up was the SALON/LAY crossing. I'd never heard of balayage and I was on a rare Thursday Google-free roll so didn't want to look it up. I thought it might be the people who carry your canoe for you on a fancy trek, or something. And LAY just didn't occur to me as meaning nonexpert at 10 p.m. Maybe I'd have gotten it quicker in the morning. Lucky for me the rest of the puzzle was easier, so when I ran the alphabet I got the happy music when I got to L.

God morgen!

I haven’t even attempted to begin with Thursday’s trickery, and am saving that for the plane. So in keeping with Wednesday’s theme (especially since it is still Wednesday where I’m headed), here were my favorite things about Oslo. Thanks to everyone for the suggestions. Two more days would’ve been ideal for getting to them all or at least more of them. 

Sight: the view of the city and the water from the roof of the opera house, which you can improbably scale like a low-grade iceberg. 

Smell: the air, which is remarkably clean and just the right amount of humid. No doubt helped by how ubiquitous public transportation is—we didn’t need to get in a car once. 

Taste: smoked salmon and scrambled eggs for breakfast at the Sommerro Hotel. I think the whole trip was worth it to me just for the salmon. 

Hearing: whatever that man was belting out at the Jul Vinterland near the Oslo Peace Center. I’m not sure what it was but I doubt I’ll ever hear it again. 

Feel: this works better than “touch” here anyway, as I was mainly wearing gloves, but more importantly didn’t feel nearly as cold as I thought I would, as the temperature hovered right around freezing the whole time. Pretty mild given the latitude and the month, I think. 

Ha det for now!
I liked it. The little yellow circles were a good puzzly mystery for a minute. Kind of a Wednesday difficulty but I've had a long day so not complaining. Thanks for a fun puzzle Mr. Bodily!

Well, I'm a few beers in and I got it in 20 minutes without Google. I guess that means it was easy, but I still enjoyed it very much. I wonder if it would have been as easy without the gold circles? Guess I'll never know
That was fun! Lots of great new clues for not-so-new answers. I really enjoyed this. Cute theme too.

No matter how long I live, I will always be a NEWB when it comes to sports talk, except for a little basketballese, but even then, I'm often reduced to just hissing SICEM!  I did learn a bit of skateboard tonight and corrected my meager  baseball vocab—I thought SWEETSPOT referred to something on the ball, not the bat, and the food fills gave me a bit of help, with ARROZ and TRATTORIA and LATTE (kind of a food).  

I'm a little worn out, what with listening to the Warriors game while I solved the puzzle. The Warriors lost—just by one point, but it might as well have been ten.  

ONTHATNOTE, my heartfelt thanks, Daniel Bodily, for lifting my spirits. It was just the puzzle for tonight—hard spots and SWEETSPOTS in equal measure, and it held my attention when I needed a break.  

We'll be waiting for your eighth.

Cute Thursday! 

Farewell my beloved ERAS tour! I had the time of my life with you!!

Answering the constructor: it didn’t need the highlighting. The aha moment would have been enhanced. 

A clever and entertaining puzzle in any case. Thanks.
Loved this one, and props to the constructor! Set a new Thursday record :)
I absolutely loved this one. Shading would have worked, but I really enjoyed the “aha!” moment I got due to the novel little yellow dots (in the app version). This felt very fresh and clever.

"I think I can hit a home run!"
"Bat's the way to do it!"

(These puns are in full swing.)

I filled in the grid only to be stumped by the circled references save “sweet spot.” I know almost nothing about skateboarding, so never would get the other connections. However, I appreciate the fact that this is a clever puzzle.
I worked in software engineering for four decades and never heard of programming. You learn something every night

Ignore last comment. Hit Submit by accident. Oops! D'oh! 

I worked in software for four decades and never heard of programming in R. Good to know. I hear pirates are very good at it

I wish I were asleep but since I'm not, here goes.... Cute and enjoyable puzzle! No numbers or shading would have elevated the difficulty but this is perhaps a nice, gentle introduction to tricky Thursdays for newer puzzlers!  

Thought the clues for SWOOP and MANTRA were extra clever!

Very much enjoyed the Harry Potter reference and even just attended Harry Potter trivia today, or maybe it was yesterday...  But as much as I love the HP book series, I'd have been equally happy if NEWT was clued as, "What the alleged witch in Monty Python and the Holy Grail allegedly turned a villager into. (But he got better)"  ☺️

As I’ve often acknowledged, I am not, and never will be, a speed solver, so it was nice for once to have a Thursday solve closer to a SWEET SIXTEEN than in the AREA of FIFTY ONE! It’s been awhile since I’ve had a PB time, so I am enjoying it, rather than wondering why this one was so easy!

 PJS was a gimme for me, at this time of year, and seems to be a rather recent phenomenon; when I still had kiddos at home I might have gone the route of matching Christmas Eve jammies, but when they were young it wasn’t really a thing. I chuckled to think that tradition might seem creepy to some— I would have said corny was more apt!
Clever and enjoyable!  Merci!

For me I appreciate any meta-puzzle that includes clue numbers in the answers, not in the clues. 

At 25A "Beautiful Mind Director Howard": my synapses just connected directly from that clue to "Happy Days" - completely bypassing the name of the director/actor who tie them together, and it took great mental efforts to figure out why "Cunningham" (i.e., "Howard Cunningham," father of Richie, played by RON Howard) didn't fit. And neither did Opie :) 

Either a symptom of my coffee deficit, or a clever clue designed to befuddle the brains of people who watched the show fifty years ago. Or both.

I’m so tired of the puzzles being this easy. It’s okay once in awhile but I want to have to really think and chew on them. When I keep breaking my average by well over a minute it stops being fun… too much more and I’m canceling my subscription.
All the puzzles this week seem easy, or I turned suddenly smart overnight.

I really enjoyed the puzzle! It didn't contain a lot of America-specific trivia that I don't recognize, so it's one of the few thursday puzzles I was able to solve on the day it comes out, without looking up every other answer. I didn't get the theme completely until reading the explanation, but had fun nevertheless!
For me, the highlighted numbers made it too easy. For a Thursday I would have preferred no highlighting and more time thinking “huh?”

Great puzzle and Deb's column today was a delight. Everything she knows about football she learned from cartoons, heehee :-) Just imagining, which cartoons was it? Was it perhaps the recurring theme from Charles Shultz Peanuts column... with Charlie Brown attempting over and over to kick a football while trying to trust Lucy's promises that she really, really was going to hold the ball up this time, and not trick him again? Good grief! he would say after he sailed through the air and landed flat on his back. Enjoy! https://www.gocomics.com/blog/3688/charlie-brown-s-greatest-misses-every-peanuts-football-gag-comic

I print out the standard layout which did not have any little circles or shading to give the game away.  Even without that, I thought this was pretty straightforward.  SWEET SPOT is such a well known term, and having just fillled in SPOT, I could see what was going on too early.

Nothing like the NYT Xword to build your Spanish vocabulary.

Fun puzzle, but not overly crunchy for a Jueves.

Well... actually just a bit surprised that almost everyone found this unusually easy. I was appropriately puzzled for quite a while. Worked things out from the crosses, but I was just close to finishing before I stopped and pondered and - the trick finally dawned on me. That was a nice 'aha' (or, "oh, of course") moment. And of course I had a puzzle find today. Might be appropriate for today. Anyway - a Sunday from March 13, 1983 by Edward Marchese with the title "Openers." And that title was essentially the only 'reveal' in the whole puzzle. Some clue/answer examples: " ... GETTING ON IN YEARS ... " : GOODBYEMRCHIPS "BUCK DID NOT READ THE NEWSPAPERS ... " : CALLOFTHEWILD "CALL ME ISHMAEL" : MOBYDICK "GRANTED: I AM AN INMATE ... " : THETINDRUM "IT WAS LOVE AT FIRST SIGHT" : CATCHTWENTYTWO And there was no reveal other than the title of the puzzle. Don't recall seeing another like that. Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=3/13/1983&g=116&d=A I'll shut up now. ...
Nice and gentle solve. Had to look up a few things, but good. And the revealer was funny!

I managed to complete the puzzle without understanding the yellow numbers or some of the answers. Didn't get the 'theme' at all until I read Deb's explanation.

I thought it was quite tricky for a Wednesday - and then realised it's Thursday. Oh dear - that was a real 2-Down moment!
Connections is delightfully different today.  If you don't normally play, today might be a good day to check in.

In response to Daniel there were no visual clues in my pdf version which made it even more fun.  Caught on right away but got hung up only looking at the across answers on the final themer; AREATUBAs are definitely not a thing.  

Nice and gentle indeed but very welcome.
"Mind repeating that?" for MANTRA - brilliant!

One of those ones where I have no idea what the theme means until I read it on the article. American football, baseball and golf clues always stump me so as a tennis fan I was happy to very eagerly fill in IGA Swiatek. A rare gold star Thursday for me so I'm happy :)
Simply have to put this out there. One fell SWOOP. Even if it’s been shared already, it’s worth doing it again… (very short) https://youtu.be/4f91IankqwA?si=9XbzffihIOlU4VGR

After finding out yesterday I’ve
been working on a puzzle with a theme
that’s already out there in the archives,
I - for a moment - thought this one
had one of my favorite clue/answer!

Mine is
[Mind repeating that?]

but answer (thankfully) is different.

Same number of letters, though!

This was a fun one!
Thank you Daniel!

Struggled in NW and never did understand the theme, but still finished under my Thursday average by a good bit.  My only gripe — not exclusive to this puzzle — is that I’ve been gaming for years and called a noob many times, but have never seen NEWB except in a crossword.  Seems a bit forced.

Just read Daniel’s note-

I found the highlighted numbers helpful
in understanding the theme.

I think you’re correct that the shorter words
being highlighted would have taken this to an
early-week level.

For me, this was a smooth, interesting solve!
Thanks again!

Last night, I was watching TV until 10:00, and then my wife asked me to do her a quick favor, so I was a little delayed starting the puzzle.  Being impatient, I wanted to get right to it, but I realized that I also craved some dessert, so I went and got myself a slice of pie to have while solving, and then by about 10:05, I was ready to go.

The pie slowed me down somewhat, because I had to keep making the choice of entering answers or taking a bite first, and the pie kept winning. Nonetheless (and despite the fact that I couldn't crack the NW corner immediately, so I did it like a Saturday, starting wherever I could and then just moving around from there) I was able to complete the puzzle in about 14% below my average Thursday time.

Recently, I have been making mention of the site xwstats.com, where, if you sync your account to it, you can get all kinds of information about your solve and the experience of all participating solvers.  (This grouping probably includes more serious solvers than any random group of solvers, so the numbers are probably better overall, but the trends should still be clear.)

Xwstats found the difficulty level to be "Very easy", with the median solver 36% faster than their usual Thursday.  80% of solvers solved "much (>20%) faster" than usual.  Median solve time for this group is currently at 10:24 (it changes as more solves come in, and usually goes up).

So for at least this group, maybe the puzzle was a bit too easy with the circles.
Oy, convoluted “themes” like this is why I often ignore themes and solve the puzzle without reference to the theme.  Having I had to look Deb’s notes to figure out the “themes”.  Too cute by half.

And now a quick comment about yesterday's comments:

It was amazing how many people complained about the Mini answer of LIRE.  And how many of those people repeated the same discredited complaint that LIRE in the plural ruined the clue.  It's as if no one ever reads the prior comments before plonking down their own.  As if it were a novel complaint that hadn't already been answered.

Pretty much everyone who complained missed the point.  Yes, you do say "The currency of Italy before the euro was the LIRA" (singular).  But "currency" can be used in more ways than one.  Not just to name the unit (in the singular), but also to refer to any amount of cash.  

"There's a pile of Italian currency on the table.  I count a million LIRE."  Those LIRE are old Italian currency.  End of case.

LIRE has been in the (main) puzzle many times; 23 of those times, "currency" has been in the clue.

Apparently, the editors (and it goes back to Farrar in 1951) are fine about cluing LIRE in the plural with the word "currency".  And they are not wrong.  At the same time, the singular LIRA has also been clued using the word "currency" 37 times.  So you just have to get it on the cross.

At least I have to admire the adamant certainty in the tenor of the complaints!

I solved today's puzzle in x minutes Had there not been the little yellow circles, I would still have solved the puzzle in x minutes, but spent the next x minutes (and possibly x hours) trying to figure out what it all meant. Now what am I going to do with all that free time?

Sign me up on Andzrej's Team Świątek. If I can figure out how to type it, so can the Gray Lady. (Pronouncing correctly it might be a different matter.)

ON THAT NOTE, I have no problem with entries in foreign languages, but mucho arroz en una paella, all in one quarter, seems a bit . . .mucho, doncha think? (OTOH, my local fusion trattoria serves a mean matcha latte.)

Three answers were highlights for me:

TWO 
THIRTY
THIRTYTHREE
I print out the puzzle, and there are no visual highlights in the printed version, so it made things a little trickier.

I appreciate that our constructor worked quite hard to make this one fall into place. That said, I can't say all his effort translated into comparable enjoyment for this solver. Got the theme easily enough---from AREAFIFTYONE pointing to CODES---and solved the puzzle without assistance. In the end, I found myself a bit let down, and almost longing for a traditional rebus.

Sometimes it seems to me that themes are becoming increasingly gimmicky. Guess that's OK on a Thursday, but I'm starting to wonder if having a "themeless Wednesday" twice a month might be worth a try.
Nope.  I don't get it.  Thank goodness for the GamePlay column.

I found this one to be relative light and breezy for a Thursday. I enjoyed the theme, and agree with what some other commenters have said about the clues being a bit too obvious. 

Personally, I think no indication would have been too subtle for my taste. 

Maybe I’d go with something like a * in the clue of our special entries. 

It certainly didn’t detract from my enjoyment though!

I wish there was a way to hint the theme/trick clues without going to the info button on the puzzle.  I don’t want the answers — just a nudge!
Enjoyed the puzzle just took me a minute to get the trick

Naw, naw, this wisnae easy!

I tried hard to think of a 4 letter word that meant 'can' (as in Yes we can) or can as in 'can of cola'. 
As for the bat - I am still mystified - does SWEET SIXTEEEN connect to an actual clue? Even more mystified by CATCH TWENTY TWO and AIR - but you all seem to find it so easy! I assume everyone knows lots about surfing, even if you don't live near the sea; I confess to feeling dispirited. Area 51 .... had no idea. Toon and Boots.... Deets ....
As for SICEM?! NBA STARS? REUP!

Yet I found Mon-Wed really easy!
At least I got TUBA and BALAYAGE. And I learned about the Dred Scott decision, of which I knew nothing. 
Onwards
Nice crossword!
Solved this puzzle with MUCHO GUSTO.  So nice to be able to count on something fun to do on a Thursday morning.
Wordle, Connections and this puzzle....a trifecta of chewy challenges today...no lie!
Ok I give up. On my phone there is no title of the crossword like there would be in the paper. How do I find it? I take it this title is the “theme”, correct?

Great puzzle!  It took me an embarrassingly long time to figure out  the relation between, e.g., "sixteen" and "16", even though it was staring me in the face.  Yes, the little visual circles were a great idea.  Thank you, Daniel Bodily, though I do have a hard time believing that that's your name.  At any rate, bravo!

Goodness gracious!  I know I have solved the puzzle, but I definitely do not "get" the puzzle.  Phrases with numerals.  Whee.

I guess my best moment was instantly knowing 39D.  I got that in "one fell....."  Yeah.  
Slow JAM?

And I see we must all learn to think of our young folks's jobs or dissertation topics because CODing and CODES are more up-to-date than hoary old Swooshes UFO sightings, and WWII novels.
It is also a good idea to bone up on your French, Spanish and Italian.  And Taylor Swift.

See youse guys tomorrow.

Fun Spangram today: 

Strands #284
“Shape and bake”
🟡🔵🔵🔵
🔵🔵🔵🔵

No spoilers please until after the View All Replies button.

Deb is correct that some people will find this too easy for a Thursday. I understand that many peopl wouldn’t agree, but in about 50 years of doing NYT crosswords, I am finding the later week puzzles to be getting too easy! We can’t all like every puzzle, and I think it’s fair to have harder puzzles at the end of the week. I don’t do the Monday, Tuesday or Wednesday puzzles, so I don’t get 7 puzzles a week either. But I want a challenge on Thursday, Friday and Saturday, please.
Very fun puzzle! But I did not see any circles or highlights when I printed my puzzle from online...? So I totally missed the theme. Anyone else have this issue?

I want to be a test solver, that would be so fun!

I thought this was an incredibly clever theme. But like some others, I would have preferred it without circles. Since the concession was made to include circles, perhaps 16A, 22A and 51D could have been dashes instead of straightforward clues. Understanding the theme may have been more integral to the solve in that case.  Or, maybe that's just a crazy suggestion.

This was fun and - as the crossword usually does - made me smile. For myself, Mr. Bodily, I *personally* would have preferred not to have the indicators, but I certainly recognize why the editors wanted something and I'm glad you settled on this compromise rather than agreeing to give the trick away too easily. It is a Thursday, after all, and I wish a very good one to my fellow puzzlers!
So much uniqueness today with this fun solve and Connections.

I solved easily enough without understanding what the circled numbers were all about, and had to scratch my head a bit even after reading Wordplay. Not that I imagined SWEET SIXTEEN had anything to do with a baseball bat, but nothing else fit. I don't know skateboarding terms, so CATCH TWENTY-TWO seemed as good as anything else, and AREA FIFTY-ONE? Well, I get it now. It's a bit like solving Connexions while getting the last category only by process of elimination, as was my experience with that game today.  
   So ... clever and worthy of admiration, but I'm not hugely enthusiastic.

I have enough trouble reading the teensy-tiny faint numbers in the Dead Tree edition of the NYTXW without having to see things around numbers that are even fainter and teensy-tinier.  I thought there was something that looked like very pale ANTS around/next to/on top of a few numbers in the grid -- but I wasn't sure and decided not to worry my pretty little head about it.

Luckily I solved without having to make out the faint marks.  I did it via word pattern recognition, since I would have thought the fat part of the bat was the SWEET SPOT (why SIXTEEN?);  don't know why you CATCH TWENTY-TWO (though I have heard of "hang ten") and I know nothing about AREA FIFTY ONE, though it rings a slight bell.

A really easy Thursday.  Biggest problem for me was wanting CHET instead of ETTA.  But I didn't write it in -- anymore than I wrote in LODE at 1A.  Even though I would much rather strike a LODE than a POSE -- hey, it's Thursday and a girl can't be too careful.  Always, always confirm an answer -- that's what I say.  Anyway -- a perfectly pleasant puzzle that belonged on an earlier day of the week.
The word is Noobs not Newbs

Of course I knew Roger B TANEY, because the Coast Guard cutter that was named for him is a museum ship in Baltimore's Inner Harbor. (He was a local boy.} They took his name off the vessel a few years ago during the cancel-mania, and now she's just 37.
I did not figure out the theme, but enjoyed the puzzle anyway. I had SHOWBOOTED instead of SHOWBOATED and thought it was fun wordplay until my puzzle wasn’t correct!

Thoroughly enjoyed this experience! Including the numbers in yellow. I actually did struggle at first and the northwest was the last to fall (can for JOHN, d’oh!!!)…so many great clues. The theme answers started coming together slowly and I then saw the relationship to the numbers , then when I saw “SWEET….SPOT” it was a second  aha moment that made it so fun.  I’m in awe.

couldn't make heads or tails of the top part at first, but when i saw AREA FIFTY ONE it clicked. and seeing my favorite novel, CATCH TWENTY TWO, put a smile on my face! plus some really fun fill here (word with slow or strawberry and word after one fell stuck out to me). first time commenting on a crossword but very well done!
Thursday vibes but solved like a Monday. Despite the easy solve I had the “clever constructor” smirk once I got the theme.
Didn't understand the theme until I checked the column after finishing but the fill was pretty forgiving
So what if it's a little easier than the usual Thursday? Maybe that's a helpful way to ease in, for some people new to the Thursday puzzles. I once found them mystifying, too.
What is “area sect” (three-digit numbers in parentheses)?  I wanted it to be “area code”.
No problem completing the grid, but had to read the col to get the clue. Never would've otherwise.  Blushworthy but fun.

An easy Thursday is forgivable if the theme is worth it. I did not feel that this was fun or satisfying enough to excuse the simplicity of the solve. 
Following an easy Wednesday, I'm feeling disappointed. I guess there is always tomorrow!
Easy but fun!  Great theme answers, nice fill.  Know the next days will bring challanges.

It's nubes not newbs!

I loved it, but I am curious what it would have been like to solve it w/out the circled numbers. 

Or maybe even if SPOT hadn't been right by SWEET. Swapping the placement of 19A and 52A would have been an easy fix for that. (Though not for the constructor who would've had to completely redo the puzzle.)

I almost got chosen as a test solver, but for some reason I failed the psych evaluation.

(Too many cross words?)
Took me some time to grok the highlighted numbers. However, they were a cute touch for this clever but kinder than usual Thursday. More pleas Mr. Bodily.
Very clever! Touche!

No highlighting in the app on my rather old iPad so I didn’t get the theme til I read about it here. 

Nice puzzle anyway. Took me 13 minutes or so. Could have finished a little faster if I could have deciphered the theme.
Very nice. More like a magic trick than a gimmick.

I could tell there was something going on with codes, but thought it had something to do with swapping Cs for Rs or something like that … so found it harder than I needed to until the penny finally dropped. Also got stuck in the NE because I couldn’t think of a word with a j and an h for the longest time.

Might be time for a vacation.
Fun theme Thurs! Took about 5 extra minutes to solve NE corner because I had so confidently typed in SAn for 23A.  *facepalm*

Between 1A and 19A, I was afraid this was going to be a baseball theme. Glad it wasn't.

After getting past that fear, it turned out to be a bit easy for a Thursday. Had the visuals shown in the paper PDF print-out, it would  have been way too easy. Yeah, yeah, I know:  look at the newspaper PDF. I do if there are any hints such as a weird grid or oddly formatted clues. 

What other movie titles might work ?  Oceans Eleven?
I solved the puzzle without understanding the gimmick at all, and was a bit surprised when "Congratulations!" popped up on the screen.  I had to read this article to "get it".
I adored this! Wish I could do one like it every single day. Five stars, heart emojis, etc.

Great puzzle! The first few minutes were frustrating - then I “got” the theme and admired its cleverness. Although I came in under my Thursday average, I personally found the clue difficulty appropriate for a Thursday.

Lovely Thursday puzzle with a fun twist! TIL “balayage.” 

I was so sad to have to remove “thesweetspot” from 19A, but very pleased to get it back again with some help from 16A. I wish there had been a couple more of the theme clues—they were delightful!
This crossword was thought provoking yet a fun solve for a Thursday. As an amateur crossword solver, this puzzle was a delight.
I do have to say, thank you for helping me set my best time for a Thursday puzzle!
Enjoyed this outing, however, the BEGAT clue turned into the song from Finian's Rainbow.  It's such a fun song but I don't think the emus would approve -  too much "begatting" going on.

Definitely my favourite puzzle in a long time, and on a Thursday no less!! I actually gasped out loud when I worked out the trick. So clever, some really fun clues (31d, 61a), and no annoying fill either. The kind of puzzle I wish I could do again for the first time.

I gotta be honest with ya Daniel -- I hardly ever figure out what a puzzle's theme is until I've solved it. So whether the clue numbers were highlighted or not wouldn't (didn't) make any difference for me. I thoroughly enjoyed the puzzle just the same.
As a computer scientist, it was really cool to see the concept pointers conveyed in a crossword puzzle. Thanks!!
Once I got areafiftyone it all came clear. Loved that.
Hi! The circled numbers didn’t affect my solve that much but when I read Deb’s column and I understood how they worked I enjoyed that and I think they added something extra! Great job.
Very nice. Enjoyed.

Late puzzle finds. I'll probably re-post this tomorrow. Two quite similar themes. First - a Sunday from November 18, 1994 by George P. Sphicas with the title "Double doubles." A couple of clue/answer examples: "Baseball's Bando greets Indians :" SALSALUTESUTES "Landers reveals her weight to the nth degree :" ANNANNOUNCESOUNCES And some other theme answers: SOLSOLACESACES GENEGENERATESRATES IMPIMPORTSORTS PROPROPOSESPOSES And there were more. Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=11/18/1984&g=23&d=A And then a Sunday from June 20, 2021 by Michael Lieberman with the title "Familiar Surroundings." I might have done this one but didn't remember it. Some theme answers from that one: CONCONFUSESFUSES ELONELONGATESGATES ANAANAGRAMSGRAMS APPAPPRAISESRAISES PROPROCURESCURES And here's the Xword Info link for that one: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=6/20/2021&g=54&d=A I'm done. ...

Thank god for this explainer because the theme, while clever!, was truly lost on me.  The I did manage to answer all the clues but not understand the theme.  Embarrassingly, this happens to me often so I just chalked it up to "oh well it's a Thursday puzzle". 

I know that if a puzzle stretches my imagination for what crosswords can be it's a good day, even if I'm flustered and confused.  

Thank you Mr. Bodily for the challenge!

I spent so much time trying to match the second half of the arbitrary words to a different direction of the circled numbers… 

I was able to complete the puzzle without hints but I don’t agree on this being clever.

Enjoyed the puzzle and my time was quite a bit below average (no complaints). But I was feeling a bit dumb not to have grasped the theme at all. When it was all done I was peering at those 3 little gold numbers and wondering what point I'd missed. Did finally catch on. But I'm relieved to read that several others made no use of them in solving either and only figured them out when done. So my vote to the constructor is that they were cute but not necessary.

@Barry Ancona 

For myself, I generally prefer having to ferret out the trick without the visual cues.  I especially enjoy spotting a rebus that hasn’t been signaled. @Pani Korunova

I heard you admonishing me in my head when I realized my San needed to be São for Brazil.
@Justin Haha! I’ve become quite the scolding school marm! It’s just that Portuguese is like Avis — they have to try harder! I feel like I’m the PR person for their language 🤣

@Andrzej 
The matching PJs is a Christmas Eve/Christmas morning thing for many families. Generally flannel with some kind of holiday theme. Not arcane here.

@Andrzej It’s an American English puzzle with anglicized answers. Every other day there’s an answer like “ANO” in the place of “año”. And in Spanish believe you me those words mean two very different things.

@Chris g 

In the answers, sure, but the clues? And it's not ok to misspell Spanish, either. Getting proper names wrong seems especially wrong.
Also, do you think Polish crosswords misspell English names because their pronunciation and spelling make no sense in our own language?

@Andrzej 

Family matching PJS took me the longest.... And I have family members (extended, I add to distance myself) who do it and post on social media, send for holiday cards, etc. It's a whole thing.

My experience is that it's usually a winter holiday thing. 

On the one hand, what was it the other day, AS YOU DO, on the other hand, I incline toward your creepy assessment even though it's not really arcane here.

@Andrzej The marks are generally not understood and/or ignored by Americans. I understand that the Polish letters in today’s name are very different than the ones in the puzzle. There’s no way 99% of Americans would know how to form those letters even if we knew they existed. Also, the crossword puzzle format here doesn’t allow for accent marks.

Today’s puzzle had a Portuguese word written as SAO when it is actually spelled são.  The other day, there was OLA when the correct spelling is olá.  There are other words, such as those for grandparents, which would really cause a stir! Grandma is avó while grandpa is avô. 

The marks do change word meanings but the American puzzle format will probably never include them.  We have to just roll with it. 

Also, imagine (just for kicks) if pronunciation came into play! ARROZ in Spanish is pronounced vastly differently than ARROZ in Portuguese. Same word, same meaning, same spelling but entirely different pronunciation! 

I hope you have a great day 😊

PS:  We do wear matching PJS for Christmas in our family. 🤣🤣🤣

@Andrzej I have to agree with with you about using diacritics in the clues. There’s no rationale I can think of. I wonder what puzzle editors have to say about it.

In fact, I remembered the same clue in a puzzle by Jess Rucks on Apple News Plus on Saturday, Dec 7.  The item was clued as Świątek on there (57D). Interesting 🧐!!
@HeathieJ I think it's still ok to actually say that wearing matching PJs is a Christmas thing.

@Andrzej Regrettably, you’re right and it’s an intentionally disrespectful choice. In a baffling decision I can only imagine was a compromise between writers who wanted to spell correctly and aging editors resistant to change, the New York Times manual of style allows diacritics only in words and names from French, Italian, Spanish, Portuguese, and German. Also, only diacritics that are common in those languages can be used in the paper.

@Andrzej 
Welcome to Americana!  Spending the holidays in Brazil, or Brasil, if you prefer, where accents are everything in the Portuguese language, but not so much in our everyday English language. If you have been a a nice boy during the year, may Santa Claus be kind enough to you and yours to leave a pair of matching Grinch PJs under your tree on Christmas morning.

@Pani Korunova 
To that, imagine what you might be served if you enter a sorveteria and order a coconut ice cream using the wrong accent. Fortunately, the Brazilian people are generally forgiving towards Gringos like me here in the interior.

@Andrzej I understand omitting diacritics from answers. But its completely disrespectful to get the names wrong in clues. Particularly when they regularly use accents in clues to imply a word is in French/Spanish

@nash.mark 

Actually, we do presents on Christmas Eve. Christmas morning is for hangovers (and recovering from pasterka, the traditional Christmas Eve midnight Mass, for those who participate).

@Lauchlin 

Thank you for the explanation 👍🏾

@Andrzej Unfortunately, she is most commonly known as Swiatek in the anglophone world. This picture is from Wimbledon: https://www.tennismajors.com/wimbledon-news/swiatek-with-rybakina-gauff-with-sabalenka-everything-you-need-to-know-about-the-womens-singles-draw-at-wimbledon-770319.html Even the French, who do have diacriticals, simplify. This is from Roland-Garros: https://www.threads.net/@stansportau/post/C7tfXWRxIAL Apparently, she allows (or can't control) the use of the simplified version in her professional career. Even when you Google "Świątek", most of the hits give you the simplified version. So, for better or worse, this isn't a NYT-specific issue. I think the issue is that although the Ś and the ą have specific pronunciations in Polish, they don't mean anything in English. Or even French. If it makes you feel any better, they do the same thing to Vietnamese names.

@Janet 

Not sure your point. I have no issue with Christmas. Merry Christmas is what our cards will read. I object to no holiday greeting.

I also happen to know it isn't just Christmas that people do matching PJs....  But that it's especially winter holidays.  

Thanks for letting me know it's okay to say Christmas but I'm sure both ways are okay.  🤷‍♀️

@Andrzej 
Did you ever notice that Barry and Andrzej don't post at the same time? Hmm.

@Lauchlin 
I do not think it is "intentionally disrespectful."
I put it down to laziness....partially.
The other part:  we never received instruction about diacritcal marks at all.  They are not common in American English.  What little I do know ("French has two accent marks:  one goes thisaway and one goes thataway") is pretty much picked up reading books.
Because I had instruction in German in early grades (DOD schools overseas during Army of Occupation days) I knew the umlaut...but my college literature prof had never heard that word...

It's very hit or miss, whether we know a mark, know what it's called, know where to use it, etc. 
I beg you to cut us a little slack, though:  I have trouble recalling my own phone number (it's new, and I never call myself!)  So....  I'm sorry, but there it is.

@Andrzej - Nowadays, on my phone, the letters of the Polish alphabet are fully available to me without installing a Polish font. This was not true fifteen years ago. The Czech letter ý and Welsh ŷ are even more recent in their inclusion, as are the letters ħ, ď, ë, ļ, ğ, and so many more. The underdot letters (a, e, t, d, r, etc. with a centered dot below) used in many languages are still not available. Editors have to consider the systems that will realize their product when it gets syndicated to other publications, or uploaded on different platforms. The simple fact is that not every mark is available to everyone.

The New York Times - not just its puzzle pages - spells Erdoğan as Erdogan. It just does. It uses Izmir, not İzmir. It just does. Brzezinski has never been spelled Brzeziński in an American newspaper. Practical, yes. Disrespectful is in the eye of the beholder, it seems.

@Andrzej 

I would hope not but I've found myself shocked and bitterly disappointed with things here before....   No more so than this last last 6 weeks, so I guess I can believe almost anything now.

@David Connell 

As always, you make a good, rational point, and you do so in a stoic manner that speaks to me. Thanks :)

Still, I am sure you also understand where I am coming from - as a Slav and as a Pole I have faced discrimination many times, and I am sensitive to any indication of a lack of respect for our culture and language. It may look like I'm overrecating but it's honest and genuine.

In the end I choose to be happy Iga Świątek's name sometimes is spelled correctly by Anglophones (thank you for the info above, Pani Korunova <3) rather than obssess too much about it being spelled wrongly.

It is also encouraging almost everybody here acknowledges the issue, even if some do not see the need (or maybe a practical possibility?) to adress it. Thank you all :)

I think when the term first appeared it was NEWB, which then morphed to "noob," which further morphed to "noobian." 

You then had the term "owned," meaning prevaiing over someone decisvely, which resulted in the common typo "pwned," which in turn got adopted over the earlier form and subsequently respelled as "pooned." 

All of which combined in the phrase "pooned like a noobian."

Steve,

A solver can correctly fill in all the squares in this puzzle without understanding the theme; it's a crossword. 

Having done so, a solver may then notice the theme without having used it to accomplish the filling.

I prefer to try to discover the theme while solving, and I personally don't consider a puzzle solved until I do understand the theme, but those are my choices, not requirements.

@Bill - I tried responding earlier, but whatevs.

It’s not about what NYT can write, print, edit. It’s about maintaining viability after syndication, on multiple platforms, through an infinite number of variables.

The front page of the NYT writes about Erdogan visiting Izmir, not about Erdoğan visiting İzmir.

This is not a crossword editing issue. It’s not an issue at all. The Czech government meets in Prague, not v Prazu. In American English Warszawa is Warsaw, like it or not. In Polish papers Paris is Paryż. I wonder how very upset Andrzej gets every time his Polish newspapers call it Paryż instead of the _proper_ name Paris?

@Jane Wheelaghan SWEET SIXTEEN connects to the clue at 16 Across, which is SPOT, giving you the answer to "Part of a bat that gives the best contact" or the SWEET SPOT.   In the same way, CATCH TWENTY TWO becomes CATCH AIR, and AREA FIFTY ONE becomes AREA CODES.  

Slang terms are of course more difficult in the "other" version of English.  I don't do very well with British puzzles, myself.

@Jane Wheelaghan 
Can and John are both slang terms for the Loo.
The Suns are a basketball team and NBA is the National basketball ball team.
Deets is short for Details.
Sweet Sixteen is a real thing but you're supposed use the Sixteen as a hint to look at the answer at 16 across to get Sweet Spot.  The Sweet Spot is the place on a baseball bat where if you make contact with the ball there, you will make connect for a really good hit. 
Toon is short for cartoon. I never heard of the one clued.

@Jane Wheelaghan Do you solve the puzzle in print, on the web or in the app? If the circles (just the numbers are circled, not the entire square) are missing, please send a not to NYTGames@nytiimes.com so they can let the producers know.

@Jane
Also, if you solve on an iPad or phone, you need to have Show Overlays turned on in your settings to see the little circles. The setting are under the Gear Icon.

@Vaer 
On the crosses, the "toon" is DORA (the Explorer) whom you'd know only if you had children younger than mine (both in their 40's)...so I was out of luck there.  I guess she runs around the globe with a monkey (oh, right....quarantine? She don't need no stinkin' quarantine!).

@Vaer 
Thank you. I think in the US you have a gift for inventive slang and abbreviations. I wonder if the sweet spot is a scientific fact, or an invention?

@Jane Wheelaghan I think cricket bats also have sweet spots. More formally called the center of percussion… when the ball hits at the center of percussion, the bat holder feels minimal reaction force from making the hit. https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Center_of_percussion The ball’s energy tends to go into vibrating the bat, so there is often a sort of ringing sound when the ball hits the sweet spot. Probable bells, gongs, and other idiophones (! a hard crossword word) have sweet spots. Maybe somebody has already mentioned… US area codes are like… I think… STD codes in the UK. In the US ours are always 3 digit and… Canada, from the US, has no telephone country code, but Mexico does. The UK has whole non-English languages, instead of the diverse US slang. There are online calculators in the US they can place where someone grew up by which set of 30 or so words they use… “pop” versus “soda” etc. Can make crosswords hard! The JOHN is the CAN is the HEAD is the LOO is the FACILITY is the TOILET is the COMMODE. And a lot more. I suppose a NYT crossword from 1942 probably had more Manhattan regionalisms… when the NYT was a bit more parochial… than does the current one which is available worldwide (and probably on the space station) with just a click.

@sonnel 
And there's also 'bathroom' even if there's not a bath in the room!
The posh word is 'lavatory' and 'toilet' was/is deemed for the lower classes. My father, on the other hand, would have said 'lavvie' in the shipyards of Leith. A commode is a toilet set into a chair and can be used for those who cannot walk to a toilet. 
I lived in NYC in 1974-75 and no-one I knew used can, john or head - was it considered a bit rude that long ago?

@Jane Wheelaghan 

yes, can, john, and head would have been a bit rude in 1975. Not unknown, but not proper language for polite company.

Hi Kris
Only Sunday puzzles have titles that hint at the theme.
Monday through Wednesday puzzles have themes and will usually have a clue and answer that will let you know what that theme is.   Thursdays are tricky and generally you have to figure out what the trick is on your own, though sometimes there are hints. Fridays and Saturdays are themeless. 
The Wordplay column will explain tricks and themes if you want help.

@Travis It didn't used to be.
 Websters describes noob as  a shortening from noobie, a variant spelling of newbie.
And their word history has the first known usages as:
Newbie - 1970
Newb - 1983
Noobie - 1995
Noob - (also) 1995

So 'newb' is at least 12 years older than 'noob', and 'newbie' is very much in current usage.

Sue,

The constructor asked all of us for our personal take on the visual hints. I gave my personal take. Other commenters gave their personal takes. And now you have given your personal take. I don't think there is anything for you, I, or anyone else to remember.

@Barry Ancona

I think you missed her point. She was saying opinions here are not a true random sample of all NYTCP solvers. I agree but would say "not *necessarily* representative".

Mr Dave,

The constructor asked Wordplay readers to offer their personal opinions. Wordplay readers offered their personal opinions. Nineteen readers added their personal opinions as replies to my post offering my personal opinion. I have no opinion on whether Wordplay readers are or are not representative of all NYT XWP solvers,
but that isn't something I need to remember when offering my personal opinion. It would be something to consider for someone seeking "a true random sample of solvers."

N.B. For those who read the comments but not the column...

Constructor Notes
This was a fun little puzzle I made while on a family vacation to Bear Lake in Utah. It came together nicely once I allowed the grid to be 15x14 in order to accommodate the central theme entry.

I originally submitted this puzzle without any extra visual cues, such as the number highlighting. Later, after it was accepted, I was told that many of the test solvers struggled to understand the gimmick. The editing team suggested shading the smaller theme entries. I pushed back a bit and suggested highlighting the numbers only, hoping to preserve some of the challenge I felt a Thursday puzzle should bring.

What do you think? Do the extra visual cues in this puzzle enhance or detract from your solving experience? Please let me know in the comments.

Happy puzzling!
